script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I want to start with something that has always intrigued me about these chapters. The Bible opens with 'in the beginning God created the heaven and the earth,' but Moses 1 doesn't begin there. Instead, it starts with God speaking directly to Moses about who Moses is. Why do you think the Lord frames the entire Creation narrative around personal identity first?

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a profound way to approach it, Sarah. Notice in Moses 1:4, God says, 'And thou art my son; wherefore look, and I will show thee the workmanship of mine hands.' Then in verse 6, 'And I have a work for thee, Moses, my son; and thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.' God establishes Moses's divine potential before revealing the vastness of creation. It sets the foundation that our identity shapes everything we understand about God's plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's fascinating. So identity isn't just background—it's the lens through which we see the heavens and the earth. President Nelson taught that the first thing the Lord would make sure we understand is our true identity. How does that pattern show up right away in Moses 1?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly. Look at the contrast with Satan in Moses 1:12. Satan says, 'Moses, son of man, worship me.' He immediately attacks that divine sonship by reducing Moses to just 'son of man.' Whereas God calls him 'my son' and links him to the Only Begotten. It's a clear pattern: God affirms our eternal nature; Satan sows confusion about it.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I hadn't connected those phrases so directly. What strikes me is how Satan mimics God's appearance but offers a counterfeit. How does Moses recognize the difference?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Moses remembers his vision from God. In verses 13-15, Satan commands worship, but Moses says, 'I will not... for behold, thou art Satan.' Then in verse 14, 'Get thee hence, Satan; deceive me not.' Moses clings to what God showed him—his identity as a son of God. That's what drives Satan away.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Powerful. And verse 24-26 show the Lord stepping in: 'Depart hence, Satan,' and Moses calls upon God in the name of the Only Begotten. It reinforces that our resistance relies on Christ's power and our true identity.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, and this isn't isolated. Abraham 3 builds on it by revealing our premortal existence. In verses 22-23, Abraham sees 'the intelligences that were organized before the world was; and among all these, there were many of the noble and great ones.' We were there, known by God, with divine potential.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So Moses learns his identity postmortal vision, but Abraham sees it premortally. That's a remarkable connection across dispensations. How does this multi-perspective view change how we read the Creation?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It transforms it. The Creation isn't just physical formation; it's part of God's work to help us realize that potential. After Moses sees the earth and its inhabitants in verse 27-28, he asks, 'Tell me... why these things are so?' God's answer in verse 39 is stunning: 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What a realization. Immortality for all, but eternal life—that's exaltation, living with God. How does Abraham 3 deepen that?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Abraham 3:24-26 ties right in. The Lord says to Abraham, 'These I will make my rulers; for he stood among those that were spirits... and he saw that they were good... These were ordained unto this purpose.' It's about premortal choices leading to roles in God's plan for eternal life.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I'm intrigued by how this spans from premortal organization to mortal probation. Notice the pattern of divine selection: noble and great ones chosen for leadership, mirroring Moses's calling.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. And in Abraham 3:22-28, we learn we lived as spirits, knew Christ, and covenanted. This continuity shows God's consistent pattern of revealing identity to prepare us for His work.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Let's think about the historical context here. These revelations came through Joseph Smith as inspired translations and visions. What many don't realize is how they clarify ancient truths obscured over time.

script.speaker: David
script.text: True. The book of Moses revises Genesis 1-6, providing what was lost. For instance, the Pearl of Great Price restores premortal council details rare in other traditions, aligning with prophetic patterns from Enoch to modern times.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That cultural insight makes it vivid—early Christians debated these ideas, but now we have clarity. Resolving the opening mystery of identity leads straight to resisting Satan's counterfeits today.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Satan still tempts with fakes, like artificial versions of truth. In Moses 1:13-18, he claims power like God but lacks glory. Recognizing counterfeits comes from knowing 'I am a son/daughter of God' as the core identifier.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's exactly right. President Nelson said our thinking about who we are affects every decision. List the choices that flow from child-of-God identity versus other labels.

script.speaker: David
script.text: For example, facing temptation: child of God chooses purity; mortal-only view might compromise. Or service: divine heirs seek eternal life for others, reflecting God's glory in Moses 1:39.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Profound connection. Now, circling back to the Creation frame—what's significant about seeing 'worlds without number' yet focusing on this earth?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Moses 1:33-35: God shows 'worlds without number,' but Moses beholds only this one because of inhabitants with agency. It reveals God's work centers on souls progressing toward eternal life across creations.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So the apparent vastness versus specificity resolves in purpose. Abraham 3:24 adds premortal organization of intelligences for that purpose.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, intelligences organized before the world—eternal spirits with potential. This typology connects to temple covenants, where we learn roles in God's plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I see the pattern mapping now: premortal ordination, mortal testing like Moses resisting Satan, postmortal glory. How does this integrate with the plan of salvation?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Beautifully. Christ's role is central—Only Begotten, redeemer enabling immortality and eternal life. Abraham 3:27: 'the Gods took those... and organized them' under His direction.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Modern prophets build on this. Nelson's devotional urges knowing identity first, countering Satan's confusion, just like Moses 1.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And in 'Choices for Eternity,' he says it affects every decision—mirroring how Moses's identity helped him overcome.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What hidden connection across scriptures stands out to you here?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Consider Matthew 4:1-11—Christ resists Satan quoting scripture, like Moses invoking God's name. Pattern of premortal noble ones tested in mortality.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's a deep link. Also, hymns like 'I Am a Child of God' reinforce these truths daily.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely. Now, for application: when doubts come, recall Moses 1:12-26 response. What helped Moses? Reliance on God and Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And spontaneous family discussions, like at meals, sharing how we resisted adversary that day.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Perfect. Distinguish immortality—resurrection for all—versus eternal life—exaltation through covenants.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Christ brings both: Atonement for immortality, gospel path for eternal life. Abraham 3 truths make premortal life real, affecting today's choices.

script.speaker: David
script.text: List from Abraham 3:22-28: we are intelligences, spirits organized, noble ones ordained, Christ chosen, agency given. Valuable for purpose and resilience.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: This really deepens understanding. David's insights show divine patterns consistently guiding us.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And it all starts with God revealing who we are, as to Moses.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: One more layer: JST additions in Moses expand Genesis, showing prophetic continuity to our day.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, restoring truths like God's work in verse 39, central to plan of salvation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: For listeners, ponder Moses 1:4,6 and Satan’s contrast. What choices shift when identity as child of God leads?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Study Abraham 3 premortal vision—make your own list of truths. See how it strengthens against counterfeits.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Explore Nelson’s 'Choices for Eternity' for modern application.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Notice patterns in your life mirroring Moses’s experience.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Thanks, David, for these meaningful discoveries. Listeners, apply these truths this week.

script.speaker: David
script.text: It's been a joy, Sarah. Until next time.
